awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Investigating 3-D Dispersed Smart Antenna Arrays for Nearly Full Spherical Scanning by New Radios (NRs)
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description 

The existing 4G cellular systems have stretched their capabilities to a limit that they can no longer be extended or incrementally improved to meet the mounting demand for high bandwidth-consumptive mobile services. As the demand for large bandwidth and high data rate for mobile applications is at all-time high, future 5G (5th Generation) mobile terminals must operate at unused millimeter wave (mmWave) bands. It is also expected that existing lower frequency 4G bands will continue to be needed for wide area coverage. In this project, it is proposed to investigate the performance of a new generation of smart dispersed array antenna architecture for future 5G new radios (NRs). The mmWave arrays will be integrated into recently designed 4G/LTE multi-slot antennas for interoperability between cells of 4G networks and future 5G heterogeneous cells. This will provide a unified connectivity platform for existing and emerging connected services. This fellowship will be a unique opportunity for the PI and a graduate student to access state-of-the-art facilities and advanced fabrication equipment. The project outcomes will be utilized to attract members of minority and underrepresented groups to engineering education in the Gulf Coast region. This will also boost the University of South Alabama?s recruiting effort to attract outstanding undergraduate students, and drive up new mobile-based economic development opportunities in the Gulf Coast and in the State of Alabama.

Technical Description

The objective of project is to investigate the performance of 3-D dispersed antenna arrays that will be implemented in multiple planes of mobile terminals for future 5G networks, called New Radios (NRs). Orthogonal arrays dispersedly located on various planes of NRs will be studied for Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) operation and beam scanning in nearly full spherical region. Miniaturized metasurface-inspired antenna array elements will be based on Dolph-Tschebysheff amplitude weighting, where excitation co-efficient of elements will be related to Tschebysheff polynomials. Smart beamforming algorithm will be developed for a fine scan step with narrow beamwidths in all planes. Two types of array elements will be integrated into a newly designed 4G multi-slot-based MIMO antenna system that will enable NRs to operate in almost all 4G/LTE bands, and multiple mmWave bands, such as 28 GHz and 39 GHz. This will enable NRs with a harmonized connectivity platform for existing and future wireless services. Dispersed arrays, equipped with advanced beamforming and associated feed networks will be developed using 3D printing technology. In this collaborative project, PI Latif and a graduate student will model, simulate and design smart arrays, and implement several prototypes and evaluate the MIMO performance of both LTE and 5G antenna systems. The proposed project will provide the PI a strong platform to develop a thriving research program at the University of South Alabama with a long-lasting impact on his research career in the field of 5G/mmWave technology, that will be benefit other academic institutions, and wireless and auto industries in the State of Alabama.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals in the project are to simulate and model dispersed array antennas for 5G wireless systems, mainly for handheld services. The millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequencies of interest are: above 10 GHz: e.g. 24 GHz, 28 GHz and 39 GHz bands. It is also intended to develop a system to operate simultaneously in various 4G bands along with 5G bands. Other goals are to investigate metasurface-based dispersed arrays for sharp beam scanning in a wide range.

First, from orthogonal MIMO slot-based antenna arrays, good isolation and desired bandwidth is achieved. A wide beamscanning range is demonstrated by simulation. Antenna prototypes were fabricated for the 4G design and tested. Next, metasurface-based antenna arrays are modeled and simulated in Finite-Element-Method-based simulation software: Ansys HFSS. This antenna array consists of dogbone-shapes patches arranged in a periodic fashion. Multiple ports are studied at different locations of the antenna surface to enable wide-range beam steering. The gain patterns from the arrays are investigated, which shows that the beam peak shifts as the excitation point is moved from one side to the other on the array. This metasurface is a high-impedance surface (HIS), modal analysis of which shows that the HIS operates as a leaky-wave antenna where the magnitude of the electric field decays exponentially along the 1D linear dogbone array. This decay of the field along the array length is due to the radiated power leaking along the linear array, and the field becomes negligible after a few dogbones away from a feed point. When multiple ports are excited, a significantly wider gain bandwidth is achieved, reaching a remarkable relative bandwidth of 27% despite the extremely small thickness of the antenna (in the order of a hundredth of a wavelength). The design has the potential to further improve the gain and the scan angle by adding more patches or employing a planar configuration. This kind of antenna can be used in mm-Wave integrated devices where small thickness is essential, and limited real estate is available for accommodating large antenna arrays. The use of this kind of low-profile antenna allows the overall volume of the device to be small, yet guaranteeing good functionality in terms of antenna performance. A conformal version of this antenna is also modeled which is a curved high impedance surface (HIS). It has demonstrated wide beamscanning capability if the leaky wave is excited by proper selection of the feed location. The HIS-inspired curved printed antenna exploits the leaky wave properties of a linear arrangement of dogbone-shaped copper patches over a curved ground plane. By selecting the excitation port along the array demonstrates wider beamscanning capability ranging from -34o to +34o. The curved HIS-based antenna exhibits a rather wide 3dB gain bandwidth. Several prototypes were fabricated and tested for confirming the simulations. The impedance matching circuit was designed for the practical implementation.

The PI and his graduate student spent the summer of 2019 in the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at University of California, Irvine (UCI), conducting research on metasurface-based antenna arrays. Since Fall 2020, both the PI and the graduate student have collaborated virtually with UCI in this project. Regular meetings have been crucial for the success of this project, and has provided significant professional experience for the graduate student. Students participated in the project also presented their research results at various conferences in-person and virtually. This project has enabled the PI develop a sustainable research program at the University of South Alabama, as PI  was able to secure more external grants using the research results generated in the project. This project has benefitted the Gulf Coast region as the PI has contributed to the workforce development of the region training graduates and undergraduate students at this institution incorporated the research outcomes in his teaching, especially in courses, such as Antenna Theory and Design, Electromagnetics I and II and Introduction to Communication. The synergistic collaboration with colleagues at the host site has impacted PI’s research trajectory and established him as an expert in mmWave wireless technologies. Several journal and conference publications were generated from the research.

The project outcomes were showcased locally to bring awareness in STEM education, which is one of the missions of NSF. The experience gained through this collaborative project was utilized to boost USA’s recruiting activities to attract outstanding undergraduate students to USA. Both the PI and the graduate students were actively involved in attracting members of minority and underrepresented groups to engineering education. Both the PI and the graduate students communicated science and engineering to local students and middle school teachers during their visits to the USA campus during the ‘Engineering Week (E-Week), held every year in February. The PI and the graduate students organized special session for the middle school students to discuss the research work conducted on 5G wireless devices, metasurface structures etc.
